In resume, an incomplete course.

results.content: Good: Listening to the teacher's accent is a pleasure to my ear. He really explains the code into detail, and recaps it everytime, so you know what is going on. Combining this with notes, and I know what I'm doing and what each part of a string of code means and refers to. I love that you get real world experience by building applications. Not unimportant, he uses quizes and gives you assignments! Which forces you to recap! Bad: The course lacked in helping you set up the development environment. So some prior knowledge is required there, or just look for a different tutorial. I would definitely look somewhere else to get your environment setup. Would have also been nice if there was a sort of central community page, be it facebook or a website, where students can interact with each other as well as the tutor. Overall I am very satisfied though.

- There are some jumps from one video to his predecessor, so i have to check out Github repository to see what changes instead of see in video;

- The course could have a richer experience if other methods of the Framework were presented, like route methods that can be used in route/web.php, or Model and Eloquent Methods to be more clean code;

- I really enjoyed watching the course, learned some tricks and saw some packages I did not know;

- The price of course is really fair, i feel like i have made a good deal.

This course, however, has found the sweet point between being deep and well paced.
Kati explains everything in details and the explanation is really easy to grasp.
Some people may have issues with his accent but that's not that much of a big deal. Being bilingual myself I know that maintaining a perfect accent is tough.
Hats of Kati. I'll be more than happy to share this amazing course with my juniors and other interested people in my community.
Highly recommended.

results.content:
I recently finished an exceptional MVC course, on here, so my standards have been set quite high. I was quite apprehensive about this one, mostly due to the unanswered comments in the Q&A section, it didn't look like the support was there. However, I've not ran into any problems, thus far. All explanations are clear and easy to follow, Kati tells you what you need to know and exactly how to do it. 

I only properly started the blog, yesterday, but I'm flying through it, so far and I've learned quite a few new things and I'll definitely be able to implement some extra features, once I reach the end of the lectures. I'm really enjoying the course, I've given it 4 stars, for now, as I never give 5, until i reach the end, but, it's looking promising, it's a very good course.

results.content: Needs a little less of the used car salesman approach. Learners don't need a huckster telling them how good the snake oil will be. Also, don't tell me what the instructor wants me to learn; I'll decide what I want to learn and don't really care what he wants me to learn. Tell me what the learning opportunities are, and let me make that judgement. (Why would I trust the instructor's judgment. I don't even know him.) Finally, and perhaps most importantly, the instructor's accent and lack of English language command is a real impediment. I find myself constantly struggling to figure out what he's saying instead of actually absorbing content.

results.content:
I went through half of the course and I stopped just to leave this bad review because I simply couldn't support the way he teaches.

The content is good and the instructor seems experienced. But even though he might be a good programmer, he is a bad teacher. 

Everything moves at the speed of light, you don't have time to understand and assimilate all the knowledge, you can't code along with him because he switches tabs fast, scrolls down really fast, types very fast. His accent is not easy to understand and above this he speaks (very) fast... 

For the instructor: too bad you prepared good content but you deliver it in a hurry. Is hard for someone to assimilate all this knowledge. This course is for beginners and shouldn't be so fast paced.

results.content: If you are a complete beginner this course can be taken without hesitation because you won't realize that the coding style is far away from good practices. Katy is an engaging teacher, however all is done with php, and it leads to very poor result in when it comes to user experience. A bit of javascript should be used througout the lessons as it doesn't make any sense (for instance) to use routes for incrementing or decrementing a number of items as the page will reload each time the user hits the button. Katy is able to explain very basic concepts but learners will face his lack of structure and skills when it comes to complex coding. However, his enthusiastic voice is a plus.
results.content_html: If you are a complete beginner this course can be taken without hesitation because you won't realize that the coding style is far away from good practices. Katy is an engaging teacher, however all is done with php, and it leads to very poor result in when it comes to user experience. A bit of javascript should be used througout the lessons as it doesn't make any sense (for instance) to use routes for incrementing or decrementing a number of items as the page will reload each time the user hits the button. Katy is able to explain very basic concepts but learners will face his lack of structure and skills when it comes to complex coding. However, his enthusiastic voice is a plus.

results.content:
Good projects to learn from, however, instructors delivery is "rushed" and somewhat disorganized.  Yes one could pause|play|rewind change speed to .75x|.50x, but having to constantly do this takes away from the course itself.

In the course description is states "Course is constantly updated with every new release of the laravel framework, so no matter when you get this course, you are still good to go."  However, this is not the case.  The course was written for Laravel 5.3 and instructor states it will still work as is with 5.4, except that Laravel is now up to 5.7 and needs to be desperately re-reviewed and updated.  

If the course presentation was slowed down a bit and updated I would easily give this 5 stars.

results.content:
Outstanding course.   In some specific ways, and I know this may come as a shock to laravel learners, it's even better than laracasts.

Obviously it doesn't have the scope of Mr. Way, but Kati gets results super fast.  He has a talent for logical development of *full apps*, plus explanation plus knowing when to just head down and take you through the code and installing some feature because it's faster just to do that than try to explain it in the abstract.

I skipped the first app as that focusses on the basics, the blogCMS was excellent, it uses a prebuilt template plus fluent bootstrap 3 so while this is full stack development you are learning there is little pause on niceties of custom css design which is perhaps as it should be where the focus is on delivering a complete result in the form of an app as it is here.
(Nor is a front end build process used - if you're cautious of that, you'll see the benefit of it in the results you're able to achieve at such amazing speed!)

And boy does Kati deliver!    The second app is a full featured discussion forum and the number of features and quality of finished design is simply amazing.

Be aware there is currently a slight mix up in the order of the videos for the second app, but you can work this out by referencing the github source which is provided.  Persevere - it's really worth it!

Can't wait to see what magic Kati has in store for the final ecommerce app.

The only thing that will make this course is a five stars course is by adding a complete admin dashboard section with dynamic charts and date filters with Ajax. I have purchased more than 200+ courses on Udemy, I can say that this course already has some potential to be the best selling Laravel course on Udemy. If the instructor would just focus on this course, take the extra miles to improve this course, and keep it updated at least once in two months (currently the latest update was almost a year ago), that'll actually do it!

To instructor: Don't wait for the next Laravel release to update this course. And, you don't "have" to create others courses to cover other programming language topics. You already have an amazing one that you can improve and you should proud of.

Just some of my thoughts. Thanks.
